characters: GOOD PEOPLE OF 0Z, LOOK AND SEE
SPECTACULAR AND STUPENDOUS THAN ANY THE WORLD HAS EVER SE
QZ AND THEODORA LITERALLY WALK ON WATER
CUTTENCLIP PAPER SOLDIERS PEEL THEMSELVES OFF ONE ANOTHER
TO OZ AND THE EMERALD CITY
THEN WITNESS AND OBSERVE... AS I
THE HAMMERHEADS AND FUDDLES LAUNCH THE MONKEYS INTO THE T
THE GROWLEYWOG WARRIORS START DROPPING LIKE OPIATED FLIES
DO NOT FEAR, GOOD PEOPLE OF OZ --
THE WICKED WITCH OF THE WEST
DOWN THE MIDWAY... PAST THE MENAGERIE... THROUGH FREAK SH
A SUDDEN WIND SWEEPS IN AND BLOWS THE CUTTENCLIP SOLDIERS
ARMAMENTS COULD HARM THE GREAT AND

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXT. KANSAS PRAIRIE —- EARLY EVENING A gray land under a gray sky -- everything flat, drab, dreary. A ramshackle farmhouse -- a creaky weather vane - dirt road stretches to nowhere -- but then we see, up ahe looming over the horizon: A LARGE LIGHTER-THAN-AIR BALLOO below which we find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly the Greatest Show On Earth, but still a prett big deal around here. People have come from far and wide their modes of transport and their styles of dress tellin we're in the very early 1900s. Townsfolk and farmers stroll the midway... barkers shout their come-ons... a Bearded Lady preens... the crowd oohs aahs at the Daring Young Men On The Flying Trapeze... the see, in the Menagerie: elephants and monkeys and a lion a a tiger and a bear (oh my)... then we come to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the audience gazes listlessly at the two men up on stage. The fast-talking huckster in the velveteen frock-c is none other than OSCAR ZOROASTER PHADRIG ISAAC NORMAN HENKLE EMMANUEL AMBROISE DIGGS -- a.k.a. ‘0Z'’ for short and he’s standing with his back to the second guy, who lo to be some local businessman.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Now, we don’t know each other, do we? We’ve never met, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, sir, we sure haven't.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And your name is --?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short for Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Lucky guess. Now, Frank, you got ‘em on there good and tight? Now we see: Oz’s hands are handcuffed behind his back. FRANK gives the cuffs a yank and --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They're tight all right.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Thank you, Frank -- and might I just say you’re a credit not only to your community but to the great state of Kansas itself -- ad astra per aspera and E Pluribus Unum. (Frank starts to leave) But before you go, I was wondering: Would you happen to know the time?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, sure, I... He dips into his vest pocket -- frowns -- starts patting other pockets and --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Is this what you’re looking for? And 0z triumphantly brings his arms out from behind his b In one hand he’s holding the handcuffs from which he’s ju escaped -- in the other he’s dangling Frank’s pocket watc its chain. Frank takes his watch back, seems wowed -- and turns to the crowd, takes a bow, but -- Not_a_single person claps -- everyone’s just looking at h about as animated as cows.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Heh-heh, yes, well -- please, no need to applaud -- your awestruck expressions of amazement are approbation enough. So, moving right along... I have in my hand here a flea. Can everyone see that? You in the back? (of course they can’t; there is no flea) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OZ (cont'd) Now, this is no common, ordinary flea -- no, this is a flea with dreams, who dreams of someday becoming a shining white dove. A VOICE seems to cry out from the side of the stage --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: That’s crazy!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (cups an ear) What’s that? What’s that you say?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I’m saying it can’t be done, turn a flea into a dove! The Voice is Oz’s own -- he’s a damned good ventriloquist

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: A naysayer, eh? Well then: Witness and observe. He deftly passes one hand over the other -- and now he’s holding a LARGE WHITE EGG. He places it in a SMALL, BARRE CAGE, covers it with a cloth, raises it up, snaps off the cloth, and... there’s now a LITTLE WHITE BUNNY RABBIT ins -- and Oz appears perplexed...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: But... that’s not a dove. Let’s try this again. He covers the cage once more, holds it high -- then SNIFF

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m allergic to rabbits. Then suddenly he SNEEZES -- such a tremendous ah-choo tha lets go of the cage and doubles over in two -- and the ca somehow, magically, stays right where it is just hovering in mid-air -- a pretty neat trick, actually -- then 0z straightens up and, with a flourish, he snaps the cloth o the cage to reveal: a SNOWY WHITE DOVE. Oz opens the cage door, the dove flies out, Oz takes another bow -- and thi time, one well-dressed, very ATTRACTIVE WOMAN actually do applaud. Her HUSBAND, a stern-looking character with a wa mustache and a bowler hat, silences her with a scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointment flickers across Oz’s face -- an artist unappreciated... his shoulders slump, his head droops... he quickly glances up again -- with a wickedly sly grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I_know what you want... He starts striding the stage like a barnstorming preacher

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, I can see that you’ve come here today in search of more than just Magic and Illusion. You're here, Brothers and Sisters, because of a burning thirst -- you’re here because, in these most difficult times, you're looking for something that will soothe your tortured spirits and ease your troubled minds. And I am here to tell you good people... (hands in prayer) .-+. I might have just the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drags a TALL MAGICIAN’S WARDROBE CHEST to the front of stage, flings open its double doors to reveal: BOTTLES AN BOTTLES OF HIGH-OCTANE HOOCH.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Behold, my friends, a very special batch of my very own Homeopathic Ontological Miracle Elixir -- H.O.M.E. or “Home” I call it, and believe me, there’s no better place or product anywhere on this green earth -- a hundred and eighty proof and only fifty cents a bottle! And this is indeed what the crowd’s been waiting for. The surge towards the stage, waving their money in the air.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Easy now! Easy! There’s plenty for everyone! (as he’s raking it in) Mr. Morgan, good to see you again! Mr. Gulch, how’s the banking biz? Mr. Hamilton, you’re looking well -- and your lovely wife? Oh there she is! -- glad you both could make it. MR. HAMILTON’s the man who scowled his pretty wife silent before -- and we see that MRS. HAMILTON’s standing toward the back of the tent, watching as her husband toddles off with his drinking buddies -- then she turns a very warm a inviting smile towards Oz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show’s over, the crowd’s gone. And behind a curtain t the side of the stage we find... Oz and Mrs. Hamilton -- locked in a torrid embrace.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You do know how to bewitch a man, Margaret. Your emerald eyes, your ruby lips...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: (nuzzling his neck) If I’m such an enchantress, why can’t I ever cast a spell that would get you to stay?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Stay? You mean here? In Kansas? I could never do that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Why not? I’m in Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, and you’re the only glimmer of color in this gray land.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: (laughs ) The only glimmer? And those other women of yours --?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Are mere baubles. You, my dear, are the one true jewel. (she kisses him, then) You know I can’t stay -- all this endless, empty sky -- I’m telling you it’s crushing me. I watched this land grind my Daddy to dust and I’m not gonna let that happen to me! There’s a whirlwind inside me, Margaret, and I don’t know where it’s gonna take me -- I just know there’s a better world out there somewhere, a world of color and light and beauty, where Fortune and_ Glory are waiting for me! I've got diamonds in my future -- I just know it! He said all that with considerable feeling. He says this with considerably less:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could come with me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: That’s very sweet. But we both know you don’t mean it. Besides, you know what they say: “East is East, West is West, Home Is Best.”

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You sound like a pillow in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: And I'm soft in all the right places, too.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. Another kiss -- then both pull back. Oz reaches inside hi vest, sets that bunny on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Now where were we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hamilton and his cronies have just finished the last their several bottles of snake oil.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Who’s up for more? Everyone is, apparently. They start tottering back to: INT. OZ’S EXHIBITION TENT - MOMENTS LATER The men come in, see no one, are about to turn and go whe they hear, behind the curtain: A feminine gasp and giggle Mr. Hamilton angrily strides forward, rips back the curta and finds Oz and Mrs. Hamilton, intertwined.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I can explain. (off Hamilton's glare) You're right, I can’t, which means, sir, you're in luck! (Hamilton stops, confused) ‘Cause right now, today, absolutely free of charge, you get to watch me... disappear.  And he bolts, hightails it out of there. Mrs. Hamilton pseudo-swoons into her husband's arms, giving Oz just eno time to make his getaway. Mr. Hamilton flings Margaret as and he and his buddies take off after Oz, and we launch i

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE MIDWAY... PAST THE MENAGERIE... THROUGH FREAK SH
dialogues.text: ROW -- the freaks and roustabouts doing what they can to Oz out (and it seems this isn’t the first time an irate husband’s been after Oz), then Oz ducks under a canvas in THE BIG TOP -- where he scuttles under the bleachers, spr across Center Ring -- only to find the exit blocked by Mr Hamilton and his posse. Oz turns on a dime, swiftly scale the AERIALISTS’ LADDER -- and Hamilton’s right up after h hot on Oz’s heels, then OZ GRABS THE TRAPEZE -- AND SWING OUT... centrifugal force soon swings him back -- Hamilton nearly grabs him -- then when Oz pendulums back the other again HE LETS GO OF THE TRAPEZE -- free-falls down into t TRAMPOLINE NET, then CATAPULTS right off it and SOMERSAUL OVER THE HEADS OF HAMILTON’S MEN and zooms out the exit - FROM THE LIGHTER-THAN-AIR BALLOON: We see Oz racing towar us -- he starts SHIMMYING UP THE MOORING ROPE -- fast eno that an exuberant ON-LOOKER exclaims:

dialogues.speaker: ON-LOOKER
dialogues.text: Look at him go! He’s faster than a flying monkey! And we now see: THE BALLOON HAS THE WORD “OZ” EMBLAZONED ITS SIDE. Oz heaves himself into the balloon’s hanging

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: basket -- just as Hamilton and his boys run up, grab hold the mooring rope, start hauling the balloon back down to earth -- then Frank comes running up with a satchel --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oz! Here you go! And he hurls the satchel up to Oz -- Oz catches it, tips hat in thanks (Frank, of course, is Oz’s long-time assist and shill) -- then Oz looses the mooring rope and -- THE BALLOON LIFTS SKYWARD -- out of harm’s and Hamilton’s reach -- up and up and up, Oz waving goodbye to everyone laughing -- that was fun -- but then he notices: Only Mrs Hamilton and Frank are waving back at him... everyone els stopped and turned towards the west... Oz himself looks a

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Sweet Jumpin’ Jiminy. SEEING: A MASSIVE STORM FRONT -- angry black clouds, clo in fast. Everyone on the ground suddenly breaks and scatt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for cover. Oz gulps --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Looks like we might be in for a bit of a gale. As if on cue: A vicious gust of wind kicks up, nearly thr Oz out of the basket -- a TIDAL WAVE OF DUST SWEEPS OVER CIRCUS, vanishes it from view -- then, to the west, a LON BLACK SWIRLING FUNNEL starts its malevolent descent from clouds... OZ HUNKERS DOWN, braces himself, then it hits:

dialogues.speaker: THE STORM OF THE CENTURY
dialogues.text: Plunging us into deepest darkness -- howling, hurricane-f winds -- crashes of lightning -- torrents of rain -- and is caught right in the worst of it -- it’s a HELLACIOUS D RIDE -- he’s getting whipped and whirled, bashed and batt -- bellowing Lear-like defiance:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage! Blow! A DEAFENING CLAP OF THUNDER drowns him out, and abruptly

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. OZ - ON THE FLOOR OF THE BALLOON BASKET —- MORNING Dead asleep. Soaking wet. Wisps of steam rising from his clothes because: he’s now bathed in brilliant sunlight. H twitches awake, eyes flicking, relieved to find himself:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Alive. He pulls himself up to peer over the side and sees: AN ENDLESS EXPANSE OF DESERT. Nothing but sun-scorched sa as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know where on Earth this is, but... I’ve got a feeling I’m not in Kansas anymore. THE BALLOON SAILS ON... and on... and on... and we --

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: THE SUN -- blinding, relentless -- the balloon drifts by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking very much the worse for wear. He scrounges throug his magician’s satchel for probably the umpteenth time, looking for something, anything to eat and drink. Pushing aside various gadgets and gizmos, he finds a flask, upend over his mouth, but... nothing; it’s empty. He finds a crumpled food wrapper, licks the last few specks of crumb off it... then he pulls out -- A SMALL, NICKEL-PLATED DERRINGER PISTOL... he hefts it, s to be weighing a decision, but --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No -- don’t even think it. You're gonna get out of this. -- squinting up at the terrible sun, knowing full well th if he doesn’t make it out of this searing Sahara soon, he done for. And then: The situation gets even worse. THE ENGINE STARTS TO SPUTTER AND DIE, out of fuel. Oz leaps t his feet, bellows:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No! You can’t do this! Not here, not now! NOOO! Please-please- please-please-please. -- caressing the machine -- sweet-talking to it -- he fid with it -- tries to fix it -- finally starts hammering on with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Damned technology! Fine, then -- go ahead! -- betray me you Jezebellian jumble of junk! I’ve been in more perilous predicaments than this! (beat) .-. Although, off the top of my head I can’t quite remember when. THE BALLOON is quickly losing altitude -- sinking towards desert sands. Oz realizes this could be it.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And I never got to see Paris. Or the Pyramids. Or the Taj Mahal, or... well bust my buttons!  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jagged peaks -- soaring into the clouds. And suddenly: A DESERT THERMAL SENDS THE BALLOON SHOOTING SKYWARD -- all can do is hold on and hope for the best... the balloon so

dialogues.speaker: HIGHER AND HIGHER --
dialogues.text: INTO THE CLOUDS -- a world of white -- snow-capped mounta below... Oz shivering with the sudden cold... ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAINS -- the balloon drifts out of the clouds... then it actually crosses... OVER A RAINBOW... Oz gaping down in wonder at the ROYGBIV stream of colors -- then he sees it, spreading out before like a lysergic fantasy...

dialogues.speaker: THE LAND OF OZ
dialogues.text: And from above it’s astonishingly beautiful -- a riot of color and lushness and light -- everything somehow tinged with yellow... and Oz can’t believe his eyes -- or his incredible good fortune -- murmurs to himself:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: If I’m dreaming don’t wake me. The balloon continues its graceful descent... Oz continue marvel -- then he brightens even further when he sees:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Water. Water! A RIVER -- sparkling in the sun. The balloon bumps to the ground right beside it, and Oz leaps from the basket, laughing like a crazy man, RUNS AND THROWS HIMSELF INTO T WATER -- giddily drinking, splashing, playing -- Halleluj Saved! -- but then he can’t help but notice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people, normal-sized people, all of them oddl dressed in some hue or shade of yellow, and they’re all j gaping at him. Oz comes out of the water, dripping wet -- and all the people take a step or two back. Oz nods hello

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: How do you do? My name’s Oz. And they all bow down to him! Like he’s a King or a God - and Oz doesn’t know what the hell to make of it.  11.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Well that’s... thank you -- that’s very kind. But if you don’t mind my asking: Where am I? A WINKIE MAN ventures forward -- who looks and sounds a l like the Winkie Guards did in The Movie.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: Why, you're here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, I, I understand that, but... where, my good man, is here?

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: The Land of Oz, of course!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: The Land of Oz? You're kidding me. You call this place 02?

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: Far as I know that’s been its name since just short of forever.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: If that don’t beat all... I mean, what are the odds? And the Winkie Man turns to the others and proclaims:

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: He’s here! The Great Oz is finally here! And everyone CHEERS, long and loud -- then they start hug and kissing and shaking hands with one another -- tremendously happy and relieved, and --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You people certainly know how to make a stranger feel welcome -- but why all the hullaballoo?

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: It’s just -- we've been waiting ever so long, sir -- and we are all very glad and grateful for what you're about to do!  12.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And, ah, not to be obtuse, but... what, exactly, is it that I’m about to do? A SECOND WINKIE MAN steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: Deliver us from the Wicked Witch!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: The Wicked what? But before he can get an answer: All sound abruptly stops a sudden hush -- everyone now looking west -- where we se SOMETHING... FLYING TOWARDS US -- and at first it’s too f away for us to tell what it is, but soon we see it’s:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Am I seeing what I think I’m seeing? Flying monkeys? Now I know I’m not in Kansas anymore. And as the Winged Monkeys swoop down and gently set the Y Woman on the ground, the Winkies all bow deeply again. Me THEODORA -- and she is beautiful. Dressed in an open- collared white shirt, black pants, black knee-high boots. She has quick eyes, quick movements, a quick, lively mind and Oz likes what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You can’t be the Wicked Witch.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Is that what they told you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No. But they did just mention something about there being a Wicked Witch, so --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Well, I am a Witch -- but do I look wicked to you? She smiles -- he smiles back, with charm --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: On the contrary.  13.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: They were no doubt referring to the Witch of the South, who is indeed very wicked and who is trying to overthrow my sister the Queen. (then, looking past him) Is that yours? -- gesturing towards the still semi-inflated balloon.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes, yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Why does it say “Oz” on it?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: ‘Cause that’s my name. Oscar Zoroaster Phineas Isaac Norman Henkle Emmanuel Ambroise Diggs, at your service. (tips his hat, grins) You can call me Oz.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: I’m Theodora. (then) So, Oz, tell me: What are you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What am I? Why, I’m an American -- a Kansas man, born and bred.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: But are you a Wizard? Ora Sorcerer? -- as the Winkies here seem to believe?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: The Winkies?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: These are the Winkies. You landed in Winkie County, the western-most quarter of the Land of Oz.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And they think I’m a Wizard?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t they? You just came out of the clouds, you fell from the sky, and you call yourself Oz. (really needs to know --) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEODORA (cont'd) So: Are you a Wizard? The Wizard we've all been waiting for? And Oz can’t help himself -- the showman in him takes ove

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, back home I am known as something of a Wizard -- a Wizard of Pyrotechnics and Prestidigitation -- I’m also a renowned charlatan and a Master of Illusion -- and if you good folks would permit me just a moment of your kind indulgence, allow me to both Illustrate and Amaze! He struts over to the balloon, takes his satchel from the basket -- (the satchel, by the way, also has the name “OZ embossed upon it) -- he picks out a few props and --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Okay, gather around everyone -- proximity only adds to the wonder -- can I have a volunteer? How about you, madam? That’s right -- don’t be shy... And as Oz starts his shtick we: FOCUS ON THEODORA... who’ watching Oz very closely -- watching his magic and, more important, she’s watching the effect his tricks are havin the Winkies, because: Watching 0z’s act, the Winkies are becoming more and more convinced that Oz does have Specia Powers -- that he is, in fact, a Wizard -- and it’s hard tell how Theodora feels about that... Oz finishes, takes bow, turns to Theodora and ta-da’s.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: So you are a Wizard, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Seeing is believing -- and I try never to contradict a pretty lady's eyes. He smiles -- like a fox -- she smiles back, says --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Well, then... She gives a quick flick of her hand, and: LIGHTNING FLASH FROM HER FINGERTIPS -- ARCS INTO THE BALLOON and --  15.

dialogues.speaker: KA-BOOOOOM
dialogues.text: huge hydrogen conflagration -- towering flames -- the Win shielding themselves and cowering -- Oz is sputtering --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Wh-wh-wh-what’d you do that for!

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (sweet as spun sugar) I couldn't just let you leave, could I? -- my sister would never forgive me. She could use a Great Wizard like you.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Use me? For what?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: To help her defeat the Wicked Witch once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And you think I can do that?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: I think you should come to the Emerald City and speak to my dear sister. And you should know: My sister is a very powerful Witch... you help her and I’m sure she’d give you anything you ever wanted...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Anything I ever wanted... and she can do that, your sister?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: She can make your every dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (greedy grin) Y'know that doesn’t sound half bad.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: No it doesn’t, does it? Oz glances towards the burning balloon.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And, circumstances being as they are: Tell you what. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OZ (cont'd) I will henceforth and immediately cancel all my planned and prior engagements, and I will speak to your noble sister -- Wizard to Witch, as it were -- see what we can arrange. Theodora signals to NIKKO, one of the Winged Monkeys, who flaps to her side, hands her some parchment and a quill.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: I’1l send word, let her know we’re on our way.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: We? You’re coming with me?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (writing) There could be... dangers along the way. The Emerald City’s a full day’s walk from here -- at the end of the Yellow Brick Road.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: We're walking? She rolls up her note, hands it to Nikko, who flies off.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: This one will carry your things. KALA'S the other Winged Monkey. He fetches 0z’s satchel.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: But why are we walking? You’re a Witch -- you don’t have a broom?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What would I do with a broom?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You could fly us to your sister’s.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: With a broom? I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (sees she’s not joking) Never mind. Then he leaps up on a tree stump, booms to the Winkies --  17.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Before we go I just wanted to thank you one and all for your wonderfully warm welcome and your heartfelt hospitality -- I’m never going to forget it and I hope to see around next time -- you've been a great crowd! He hops back down, says to Theodora --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: This place we’re going --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: The Emerald City.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I do like that name -- green, y’understand, has always been my favorite color. (rubs his hands and grins) Let’s go, then -- no time to waste -- opportunity awaits! They start out -- not on the Yellow Brick Road yet; the r here is just cobblestone -- Kala monkey-walking behind th the Winkies bowing deeply in farewell -- and when they ri Winkie #2 sees the troubled look on Winkie #1’s face.

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: What is it? Winkie #1 just frowns, shakes his head -- shakes off his concern -- then shouts to the others --

dialogues.speaker: WINKIE MAN
dialogues.text: Spread the word, far and near: The Great Oz is finally here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through rolling farmland, past curious-looking houses -- which all look vaguely like human faces.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: So tell me about this Wicked Witch.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Her Father was the King -- a very powerful Wizard and a very Evil King. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEODORA (cont'd) The Wicked Witch of the South is also very Evil -- and a very powerful Sorceress -- stronger even than my sister.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: But your sister’s the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: My sister has me to help and protect her -- and she has the love of the Good People of Oz. We see that Kala’s frowning, as Theodora says, musingly -

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: They used to be friends, you know, my Sister and the Wicked Witch... but she had no idea how wicked wickedness could be, or how easily friendship could be betrayed. (then) Ah -- there it is -- the Yellow Brick Road. IN THE DISTANCE: THE YELLOW BRICK ROAD -- on the other si of a thunderous RIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up close we now see that the river’s wide, fast, and deep

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: How we going to get across?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: We'll walk. Oz looks dubious -- as Kala picks leaves off a strange- looking bush. Theodora takes a few, hands them to Oz.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Here. Rub these on the bottom of your shoes. Kala pantomimes how to do it. Theodora rubs leaves on the bottoms of her boots -- Oz follows suit, then watches as Theodora steps out on the water -- and that’s onto the wa not into the water -- and Oz can’t believe it, can’t wait try it himself -- and he strides out, and when he sees he not going to sink he laughs with absolute delight, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And 0z is about as graceful as a baby giraffe -- he’s new this, and it’s hard to keep your balance when white-water whooshing and swooshing beneath your feet -- so he teeter and totters, several times he nearly falls -- laughing hi fool head off all the while -- Theodora walks across stat as a queen -- Kala wings his way to the other side -- and when they all reach dry land --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: That’s the most fun I ever had outside of St. Louis. Then he sees, right up close now, glowing golden in the s

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: But that looks... no, it can’t be. He rushes forward, drops to his knees, starts scratching the Yellow Brick, then exclaims --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It is! Look at this! This is pure, solid gold! (Theodora’s unimpressed) You don’t find this incredible?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: They don’t have roads where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Not paved with gold, no -- except in people’s dreams.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Then you’ve come to the right place -- ‘cause I assure you, Wizard, this is no dream.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Well in that case... for the behoovement of the common good and in the interest of one and all I think it’d probably be best if I took one of these little beauties along with me... He starts prying loose one of the Gold Bricks.  20.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Strictly for scientific purposes, you understand -- to ascertain and ensure that this is in fact the eighteen-carat Real McCoy rather than pyrite -- iron disulfide -- Fool’s Gold, in the vernacular. A Public Service I’m only too happy to provide gratis, free of charge. He slips the Brick into his pocket and stands.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: The Emerald City’s this way?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Follow the Yellow Brick Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz spots: AN ENCHANTED APPLE ORCHARD.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Apples! I’m starving!

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: I'd ask first if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Ask who? There’s nobody --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Them. The apples are theirs, after all -- and they can be quite picky. Oz frowns, but when in Rome... so he bows to the trees an

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Excuse me, hate to bother you, but my companions and I were wondering if perhaps you could spare us a couple of your fine-looking apples. He waits. Nothing happens. Oz glances back at Theodora, i about to just go and pick an apple anyway, when -- ONE OF THE APPLE BRANCHES FLICKS TOWARDS HIM -- like it’s swatting away a fly -- and three apples sail through the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tumble to the ground, roll to a stop at 0z’s feet.  21.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you -- appreciate it. (picks up the apples, remarks to himself) Remarkable. Then he offers an apple to Theodora, who says --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: No. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: C'mon, you’ve gotta eat.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (smiles) You don’t know much about Witches, do you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say that -- I’ve known plenty of Witches in my time, believe me. There was a Witch I knew in Wichita -- you want to talk about wicked? (shudders at the memory) She had a face lovely as a summer day -- and a heart as black as a Midnight Grave. He tosses an apple to Kala, takes a bite of his own, Theo looking as though she’s still trying to figure this guy o

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: We should go. It’1ll be getting dark soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep, dark, forboding. A YELLOW-EYED OWL hoots from a tre Below, Oz adds another armful of wood to a cold woodpile, then steps back -- as Theodora flashes lightning out of h fingertips again -- THE WOODPILE BURSTS INTO FLAME --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Someday you’ve really got to teach me that.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theodora’s staring thoughtfully into the fire -- Kala’s picking bugs off his fur (and eating them) -- and Oz is a his satchel -- slips that purloined Gold Brick into the c then takes something out...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Thought we could do with a little music. Shows her: A BEAUTIFUL LITTLE MUSIC BOX. He winds it up, sets it on the ground -- MOZART STARTS TO PLAY... and Theodora’s face lights up with an almost-childlike wonder delight -- completely charmed --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It’s Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Why’s it called a Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No, the music is Mozart. This is a Music Box -- you’ve never seen one? Then here -- take it -- it’s yours. A gift, from me to you.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Why? Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No reason -- I just want you to have it. She hesitates -- then holds out her hand...

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: No one’s ever given me something just because he wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I can’t believe that -- pretty lady like you? I bet there are lots of men out there who’d give you the world if they could.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Like I said: you don’t know much about Witches, do you?  23.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Maybe not, but I’m told I'ma pretty fast learner. (stands, extends a hand) Dance, m’ lady? (off her look) Now you’re gonna tell me no one’s ever danced with you before?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) No one ever has.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Then it’s high time you learned a little something. C’mon. And he reaches down, hauls her to her feet -- takes the M Box from her, winds it up again and sets it down -- then turns to her as the MUSIC STARTS TO PLAY --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Okay, then -- put your hand up -- like this. Good. Now put your other hand around me like so... He takes hold of her up-raised hand, puts his right arm around her, gets a little closer and says --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Now just try and feel the music, and follow me... They start to DANCE -- Kala watching them very closely -- their bodies touching -- backlit by the fire, and -- CLOSE ON THEODORA’S FACE -- and it’s true: she’s never danced with a man -- never been held by a man -- she’s ne before felt some of the things she’s feeling now...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You seem a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: This is all... new to me.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It always is -- every time. She glances up -- their eyes lock and hold. The music end and she takes a step back -- voice shaky --  24.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: I... the fire, I’1l -- I’1l gather some more wood. She flitters off into the darkness -- Kala scuttling afte her -- and Oz shakes his head, chides himself --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You're the wicked one, Oscar Diggs.

dialogues.speaker: WITH THEODORA
dialogues.text: Excited, frightened, confused -- hand to her belly, as if she’s trying to quell the strange new emotions within -- still looking at her with great interest -- then he glanc up, hears the flapping of wings and -- NIKKO SWOOPS IN -- TOUCHES DOWN -- has just returned from Evanora’s -- he hands Theodora a rolled parchment -- Theo unwraps and reads it, tells the two Monkeys --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: My sister wants me to be sure this Wizard's a real Wizard. (thinks a moment, then) Fetch me a rabbit. BACK AT THE CAMPFIRE -- Oz berates his hound-dog self --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Innocent girl like that? You oughta be ashamed of yourself. BACK TO THEODORA -- as Nikko brings her back a fluffy tan colored little bunny.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Set it down. Nikko obeys. Kala returns -- watches from a distance, as. Theodora stares fixedly at the bunny -- the bunny quiveri with fear -- then Theodora smiles, does something with he hands and, just like that: THE LITTLE BUNNY TRANSFORMS INTO A FULL-GROWN LION. The Monkeys shrink back -- ready to fly away if need be.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: (to the Lion) Listen close, then do as I say.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz is poking at the fire with a stick, when he hears: A rustling in the woods. He peers into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Theodora? That you? No response. But then he hears: A low, guttural growl. And, very slowly, Oz pulls a tree branch from the fire, t end of which is burning like a torch. He calls out again

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Theodora? AND WITH AN EARTHSHAKING ROAR THE LION ATTACKS! -- comes CHARGING out of the darkness, MAKES A MURDEROUS LEAP AT O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OZ HITS THE DECK -- THE LION GOES SAILING OVER HIM -- Oz quickly body-rolls to his satchel -- desperately tries to open it with one hand, the other waving that burning bran at the Lion -- and we see: THEODORA -- IN THE TREES -- keeping to the shadows -- mov to get a better ringside view, as -- THE LION CIRCLES... Oz, on one knee, gets the satchel ope shakes the burning branch at the beast --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Stay back! I’m warning you! (his other hand fumbling inside the satchel) C'mon -- c’mon -- where is it? THE LION ROARS -- then charges Oz again! -- and Oz, still kneeling, whips his arm out of the satchel, brings it up BANG! He SHOOTS the leaping Lion with that Derringer of h The Lion YOWLS in pain, then TURNS TAIL AND FLEES INTO TH FOREST -- whimpering -- and --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: That’s right! Run! Run, you coward! And don’t come back! (checks the gun, mutters to himself --) ‘Cause I’m fresh out of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And thus the Cowardly Lion was born -- perhaps -- and -- THEODORA -- STILL IN THE TREES -- smiles, says --  26.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Satisfied, Sister? -- like she knows Evanora can hear her, even though Evano miles away... she then gestures Nikko over, pens another quick note to her sister -- Nikko flies off with it and - BACK IN THE CLEARING -- Oz turns as Theodora comes dashin out of the woods -- she runs to him, all a-flutter --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What happened! I heard this roaring, then a bang!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: It was nothing. I just... (wipes sweat off his face) I just fended off a large carnivorous, uh, carnivore -- no big deal -- back where I come from we do that practically every day... (he sees his hand is shaking like a leaf) Decorum alone prevented me from tussling with the beast bare-handed -- so I just gave him a little taste of this -- (shows her the gun) And he went scampering off like a scared little rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What an odd-looking wand.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Wand? Oh, right, yes, well -- it certainly worked its magic tonight, didn’t it? And don’t worry -- I made sure he didn’t hurt Mozart. He hands her the Music Box -- and she’s quite touched.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Wizard. Their eyes connect again, and --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: We should get some sleep. We still have a long way to go tomorrow.  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see: Oz is asleep -- Kala’s asleep -- Theodora’s awake -- holding the Music Box -- staring at it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz, Theodora and Kala come out of the forest -- into brow hued Central Oz -- then Oz abruptly stops, seeing...

dialogues.speaker: EMERALD CITY
dialogues.text: A spectacular soaring skyline -- Sleeping Beauty’s Castle steroids -- and Oz is appropriately awed.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: The Emerald City... I’ve seen it before, you know.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: In my wildest dreams. Come on! -- quickening the pace -- he can’t wait to get there -- a Theodora laughs -- his enthusiasm’s infectious, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass through a LARGE FIELD STREWN WITH BOULDERS... T THE BOULDERS START TO MOVE... and it quickly becomes appa that the rocks are really turtle-shell-shaped concave shields, under which have been hiding: A BATTALION OF GNOMES -- short, squat, fierce-looking warriors with skin the color and texture of stone and bea so long they tie them around their waists -- and they’re armed to the teeth: Broadswords, cutlasses, battle-axes.. 0Z goes still, then sees, even worse -- ON THE SURROUNDING HILLSIDES: MORE SAVAGE WARRIORS -- a m of GROWLEYWOGS -- silent, half-clad, eight-foot-tall Aboriginals armed with knives and bows and arrows and spe -- and WHIMSIES -- who are distinguished by their extraordinarily broad shoulders and the enormous crazy- colored papier-mache MARDI GRAS MASKS they wear on their amazingly-undersized heads.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Get behind me.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Don’t hurt them. They’re here to escort us to my sister.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (hiding immense relief) They are? Then lucky for them you stayed my hand -- I was about to smite the lot of them! The Savage Horde forms a protective cordon around them, starts marching them towards the city, chanting:

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE HORDE
dialogues.text: Oh-we-oh, yo ho! Oh-we-oh, yo-ho! Then we hear: A FANFARE OF TRUMPETS -- and jump to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the jewel-studded gates swing open to reveal: Sheer magnificence -- towering towers, soaring spires, flowers, fountains -- everything glittering and gleaming -- a MARC BAND files in and leads Oz and Theodora into the city, in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BELLS are RINGING -- young girls strew rose petals in the path -- all the sidewalks and balconies are lined with WI CHEERING CROWDS -- a hodgepodge of Oz inhabitants from al four corners of the Kingdom: WINKIES from the West, MUNCHKINS from the East, GILLIKINS from the North and QUADLINGS from the South -- all dressed in different regi colors and all enthusiastically waving and fluttering gre and-white flags and pennants, and -- 0Z is eating this up -- waving to the throng like he’s a returning war hero or a campaigning politician -- laughin

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What, no fireworks?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What are fireworks? They pass through the ARCH OF TRIUMPH -- heading towards Emerald Palace -- and what Oz isn’t seeing is:  29. BEHIND THE SCENES -- EVANORA’S PALACE GUARD -- uniformed bully-boys passing out the flags and banners, and they’re making damned sure the Citizens of Em City are cheering 0 entrance with sufficient gusto -- or else... giving us a sense that things might not be quite what they seem here the Merry Old Land of Oz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand -- glorious -- Theodora leads Oz inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE JOINT CHIEFS OF THE SAVAGE ARMY nod deferentially to Theodora as she leads Oz through the enormous double door the other end of the hall, into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to stretch on forever -- and at the end there’s ano set of tall double doors which open all by themselves, in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there she is, seated majestically on the EMERALD THRO EVANORA -- THE QUEEN OF OZ. She’s also the Witch of the East. She’s older than Theodora, but no less attractive. very powerful presence -- with a penetrating gaze.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Wizard, my sister Evanora. Oz nods to her. Evanora sounds curious, almost amused --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You do not kneel.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: No, ma’am, I do not.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: But I am Queen.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And I’m an American -- and Americans kneel to no one. A beat -- then Evanora smiles -- practically purrs --  30.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Oh, Sister, I like him already. (back to Oz) An American, you say -- I’m not familiar with the word. You’re also a Wizard, I’m told.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Not just a Wizard -- the Wizard you've all been waiting for -- here, in the flesh, and at Your Majesty’s service. Another Evanora smile, then --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You've had a long journey, I’m sure you'd like a bath and a bed. These girls will show you to your room. She waves a hand -- TWO MUNCHKIN MAIDS waddle up to Oz.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: We'll speak some more at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I'm looking forward to it. Each girl takes a hand and they lead Oz away -- Kala todd after them toting 0z’s satchel. Evanora waits until they’ gone, then turns to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You're certain, then, that he’s a Wizard?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: You saw what he could do.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Yes, I did see. I saw it all. -- gesturing towards: her CRYSTAL BALL -- then --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: I saw then what I see now... (a big Big Sister’s smile) You like him, don’t you?... and you want him to like you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theodora -- almost blushing -- can’t meet her sister’s ey as Evanora comes up close to her -- circling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who can blame you? You’re still so young... and you still have feelings, don’t you? Stirrings and... yearnings... (mysterious smile) You did the right thing, dear, bringing him here... INT. OZ’S CHAMBERS - SAME 31. The Munchkin Maids curtsey their way out the door -- 0z l around the room, which is sumptuous as sin --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Not bad... not bad at all. (then, to Kala) Y'know something, Monkey? Just between you, me and these four walls? Methinks yours truly has finally hit the Mother Lode, landed feet first in the Pot at the End of the Rainbow, smelling like a rose. (grins) And if you don’t think I’m gonna take full advantage, you don’t know Mr. Oscar Diggs -- otherwise known as... The Wizard You’ve All Been Waiting For -- The One and Only Wizard of Oz! Kala frowns -- Oz bursts out laughing, and we go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz and the Sisters are the only ones sitting at a long oa table which could easily seat fifty. Oz finishes what has been a real belly-buster of a meal.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: A royal repast fit for a King, if I do say so myself.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) Sister? Leave us, won’t you? I'd like to speak to the Wizard alone. Theodora gives Oz a quick smile -- and leaves the room. watches her go -- then Evanora stands, says: Oz  32.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Walk with me. Oz graciously offers her his arm -- she takes it and the stroll out to --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: My sister’s very pretty, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yes. She is.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: And she speaks most highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Does she.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: It seems you made quite the impression. She says you just... fell from the sky...

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I do like to make an entrance.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Yes -- but why here, of all places? Why did you come to 0z? Oz shrugs -- obliquely -- maintaining the mystery --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Could’ve been happenstance... could've been serendipity... or maybe it was Destiny... could've been Fate.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, I’m glad you’re here. Come, I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Savage Guards are on either side of an Archway -- and interior of the arch is A CURTAIN OF BURNING FIRE.  33. Evanora gestures to the Guards: Begone -- they move off - then Evanora gives a little wave of her hand and the Curt of Fire goes out, revealing a STOUT WOODEN DOOR -- with i bands and multiple locks. Another wave of Evanora’s hand the locks fly open, the door swings open by itself, and Evanora ushers Oz into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal Repository of THE CROWN JEWELS OF OZ -- gemston and jewels everywhere you look -- thousands of them, sparkling with the brilliance of a million suns... and Oz gaping -- while trying to sound blase.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: This is, uh, quite the little piggy bank you've got here, Highness.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You like it? Theodora told me how much you seem to enjoy bright and shiny things. There's a TREASURE CHEST filled with GLEAMING GOLD COINS. runs his fingers through them like water -- then PALMS on the coins, disappears it up his sleeve as he moves on and picks up an Emerald the size of an Ostrich Egg.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Y'know, with this stone alone, I could buy the state of Kansas -- and probably half of Nebraska along with it.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: It’s yours if you want... Oz stops -- what? -- and Evanora smiles, says --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Along with this... And she holds up: THE DIAMOND DAGGER -- which has a 6-inc blade of razor-sharp steel, a cross guard of filigreed go and a hilt that’s totally ENCRUSTED WITH GLITTERING DIAMO

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: And all you've got to do is... kill the Wicked Witches.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Witches? Plural? You mean there’s more than one?  34.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: About --?

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: My dear sister.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Your sister --?

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: I know why she brought you here.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: She brought me here to help you.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: She brought you here to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Kill you? No. With all due respect, Highness, you've got it all wrong --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: What did she promise you? That the two of you would share my Throne and Crown? Tell me you weren’t foolish enough to believe it. (steps close, hisses) But you can believe this: After she seduced you into killing me she'd have eaten you like a spider. So take this... She grabs his hand, presses the Diamond Dagger to his pal

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: ... And prove to me you’re the Wizard you say you are -- the Wizard we’ve all been waiting for. She steps back -- and STARTS TO DEMATERIALIZE.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Kill my sister, then together you and I will defeat the Witch of the South once and for all. (vanishing) Kill my sister, Wizard -- and you'll be King.  35. She's gone -- disappeared into thin air -- and Oz just st there -- staring -- trying to process... then looks down the Dagger in his hand -- then, abruptly, he jams it in t back of his belt and goes tearing out of there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprinting -- no time to waste -- then up some stone stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz running -- shouting --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Theodora! Theodora, where are you! After a moment, a door slowly opens -- Theodora looks out with a faint, expectant smile --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Wizard? What is it? -- like she’s both scared and thrilled to find him here - ready for whatever he’s got in mind, but --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: We've got to get you out of here! Behind her we see a SHADOW swiftly sliding along the wall

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Why? What --? Then: Shazam! That Shadow becomes Evanora -- who with a quick angry flick of her hand sends 0Z FLYING THROUGH THE -- magically -- telekinetically -- bashing him up against far wall -- as Theodora wheels on her sister --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: What are you doing!

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Saving your silly life! He came here to kill you!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Theodora, no, don’t listen to her! Another flick of her hand and now Oz is GAGGING -- CHOKIN can't talk, can’t breathe -- as Evanora says to her siste  36.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me? Another flick of her hand sends Oz SLAMMING AGAINST THE CEILING -- then she BOUNCES him off the marble floor, flipping him upside down, and as he does -- THE DIAMOND DAGGER, jarred loose, falls from his belt, hi the ground at Theodora’s feet. Theodora stares.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Out of nowhere he suddenly appears -- you think that was an accident? No! She sent him here -- sent him here to destroy us!

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: No, I don’t believe that -- I --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Unless, of course, it wasn’t she who sent him... One final flick of the hand and Oz is RAMMED HEAD-FIRST i the far wall again -- knocking him cold.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was someone else... (moves threateningly near) Tomorrow I’1ll know... tomorrow your Wizard and I are going to have a little talk... And we can tell from Theodora’s expression that ‘A little talk’ means something absolutely horrible.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I‘’1ll learn the truth... and believe me, Sister... (strokes Theodora’s hair) I do so hope I find out you were nothing more than naive... Theodora reddens like she’d been slapped. Evanora SNAPS H FINGERS -- a few SAVAGE GUARDSMEN appear.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Take him downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz slowly wakens -- finds he’s CHAINED TO A STONE WALL.  37.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look who's back amongst the living. TWO SAVAGE GUARDS -- a GNOME and a WHIMSIE -- taunt Oz through the small barred grille of the thick cell door.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: The Great and Powerful Wizard himself. How about showing us a little magic, Wizard?

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GUARD
dialogues.text: Yeah, let’s see you get out of them locks and chains --

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: Perhaps he wants what the Queen’s got in store for him.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (trying not to show fear) What’s she going to do, turn me into a newt?

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No, nothing like that. (beat) Torture, more like.

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GUARD
dialogues.text: The Queen’s got a real taste for it. So do I. Slow roasting’s my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: I like a good flaying myself. Flesh makes such a fine meal afterwards. -- slurping like he’s sucking down a strand of fettucine

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: So what’s with the beard?

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: My beard?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: They don’t have barbers around here? A family of rats could be living in there and you’d never know it.  38.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but this here is my pride and joy, the source of my vast potency and strength.

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GUARD
dialogues.text: Or so those ignorant creatures believe. You want to beat a Gnome in battle, just have a whack at that beard of his and he’1ll go hieing home to his mommy quick as you please.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: And if you want to defeat a Whimsie all you've got to do is knock that great silly contraption off his shoulders and that’s the last you'll see of him I assure you! (stage-whispers to Oz) They can’t bear to be seen without their masks, on account of their woefully-wee heads -- no bigger than a Munchkin’s fist. -- miming the approximate size -- as Oz mutters to himsel

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Good to know. (then, to them) And not that this hasn’t been fascinating, fellas, but I wonder if you could do me a favor and just leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: He wants us to leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GUARD
dialogues.text: The man does need his rest.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: Aye, all that wailing and screaming he’s gonna be doing tomorrow can be very taxing on an individual. The Savages share a laugh, move from the door, and Oz sta contorting himself -- tries working his way free of the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and chains, while --  39. INT. THEODORA’S ROOM - INSIDE THE PALACE THEODORA -- AT THE WINDOW -- staring out at the night -- sitting in a corner, watching her -- as Theodora frowns, looks over at: THE MUSIC BOX -- ON THE VANITY ... she walks to it, winds up -- Mozart fills the room -- the music touching whateve left of her Witch’s heart... then: quickly, abruptly, bef she has a chance to change her mind -- she grabs a quill, scribbles a note, bids Kala --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Come here. She hands him the ROLLED-PARCHMENT NOTE and a KEY.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: Bring this to the Wizard -- and let no one else see it. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Savage Guards start hearing VOICES FROM INSIDE THE CE

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS VOICES
dialogues.text: I'll take the pinhead... I’1l take the hairy one... and I'll get the door... don’t worry, Wizard, we’ll have you out of here in no time. The Voices are Oz’s, of course -- but the Guards don’t kn that, and simultaneously lunge to the cell door and see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE CELL: Nothing. And no one -- no sign of Oz -- just those now-empty chains against the wall. The Guards fumbl for their keys -- then yank the door open -- rush inside, weapons drawn -- still see bupkis, then -- Oz drops down behind them from his hand-hold above the do snatches the Gnome’s key ring, then quick as a flash he’s the door, slams it shut behind him, and --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Fare thee well, boys! -- don’t forget to write -- and you can tell that Queen of yours I hope someday a house falls on her head! And he’s gone -- running --  40. THROUGH THE DUNGEON’S DARK STONE CORRIDORS Torch-lit shadow -- scurrying rats -- a locked iron door Oz tries one key -- then another -- finally heaves it ope only to come face-to-face with: KALA -- who’s so startled he drops THEODORA’S NOTE -- and freezes -- Oz freezes -- everything hanging in the balanc what’s the Monkey going to do? -- then:

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Goodness gracious me! We’ve got to get you out of here!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You... you can talk?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: No time for dilly-dally! We must go -- Glinda, she will help us!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Glinda?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: The Witch of the South.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (confused) But... isn’t she the Wicked Witch?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: No-no -- Glinda, she is the Good Witch -- the Sisters are the Wicked Ones. Please, I'll explain as we run -- now hurry -- this way -- come-come !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz and Kala make their swift, silent getaway, and soon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Savage Guards are being grilled by Evanora -- surroun by Savage Generals -- Theodora at her sister's side.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: «+. Strike me blind if I’m lying -- he just disappeared like smoke.  41.

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GUARD
dialogues.text: Cold smoke. Did you feel the cold?

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: I did. Like the very breath of death it was... A GROWLEYWOG GUARD comes in... hands Evanora a ROLLED-UP PARCHMENT -- and Theodora’s eyes widen, because she knows it’s the note she wrote to Oz... and as Evanora scans it

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GUARD
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, Highness, he’s a Great and Powerful Wizard, that one is, believe me. Evanora looks up from the note -- gazes at Theodora -- th sighs, gives a weary wave of her hand and says --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Take them away, and kill them. The hapless Guards are dragged off. Evanora then turns to her Generals.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Well, what are you waiting for? You find this Wizard and you bring him to me -- ALIVE! -- and whatever you do, do NOT let him reach the Witch of the South! Now GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Savages skedaddle -- and when the Sisters are alone..

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You wound me, Sister -- you really do. What am I to make of this? (reads the note aloud) ‘I’m sorry -- I never should have brought you here -- don’t worry I will help you.’ She lets the parchment flutter from her fingers to the fl

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Did you help him?

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: No, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: I do so want to believe that.  42.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: You can -- you should --

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: But how? How can I believe you, when you do this to me! You know what will happen, should this Wizard get away! He will ally himself with her --

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: You don’t know that for sure.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: But I do. Her charms are much, much greater than yours... (lets that needle sink in) «+. Or mine. Just you wait -- you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SAVAGE HORDE ARMY STORMS OUT THE CITY GATES -- hundre of them -- armed to the teeth -- a loping, quick-march pa A CADRE OF WINGED MONKEYS flying in formation above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0Z AND KALA -- scrambling up the mountain -- and as they the top, Kala glances back -- then points -- Oz looks, se THE TORCH-LIT SAVAGE ARMY on the dark plains below -- the Winged Monkeys flying in formation above them, streaking towards us, closing in fast...

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Do something!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: I don’t know -- you're the Wizard!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, sorry -- I’m fresh out of miracles at the moment. Kala studies him a beat -- then starts chugging up the hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then come-come -- keep moving -- Glinda, she will help us.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Good -- where is she?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Far from here.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Then how --?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: She just will. 43. They crest the mountain, and as they run and slide down t far side, we pull up and back and see...

dialogues.speaker: THE IMPENETRABLE MIST
dialogues.text: A thick, spectral fog sweeping in from the south -- movin across the land like an immense ghostly hand... it envelo Oz and Kala... then the mountain... and soon the Savage H and the Winged Monkeys are engulfed in an Ocean of Cloud.

dialogues.speaker: WITH OZ AND KALA
dialogues.text: Eerie, dreamlike -- Oz can’t see a thing.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Here, Wizard. Oz moves towards the sound -- finds Kala --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Glinda did this?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- yes-yes -- I told you, she's a very good Witch. Then we see: A glow. Kala’s holding in his paw: IRIDESCENT ORB -- the Orb’s a Magic Compass.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Take my tail. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog-blind, floundering, disoriented. THREE GENERALS are clustered together -- a GNOME, a WHIMSIE, and a GROWLEYWO

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GENERAL
dialogues.text: It’s no use. We’ll never find him in this.

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GENERAL
dialogues.text: The Queen won’t be happy.

dialogues.speaker: WHIMSIE GENERAL
dialogues.text: Is she ever? Nothing we can do. (then) You think he did this?

dialogues.speaker: GNOME GENERAL
dialogues.text: They say he came from the clouds -- now here we are in one -- I’m sure such a thing’d be easy for a Wizard like him. The other two Generals nod, seem to agree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illuminated by the Orb. As he walks, Oz plays with that G COIN he pilfered, deftly rolling it through his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: So: you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: My name? My name is Kala.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Kala. He sticks his hand out -- and Kala hesitates -- no man’s wanted to shake his paw before -- and, as they do so --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I’m in your debt.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Don’t thanky-thank me yet, not till we make it safe to Glinda.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And you're telling me she’s a Good Witch?  45.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- yes-yes -- a very Good Witch -- the only Good Witch left!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: And Theodora...?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Quite wicked, but not all the way wicked yet, not like her sister -- no -- but soon, I think, soon-soon!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (after a moment, quietly) She had me fooled, you know. They both did. Kala laughs -- a real ooh-ooh-ah-ah Monkey Laugh.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I know! But don’t feel bad, Wizard -- you’re not the first man-man to be blinded by a pretty face and pretty promises -- lots of men-men just as foolish as you!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Thanks -- I guess. (then) Tell me something: The other Monkeys -- can they talk too?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: No-no, only me. Thanks to Glinda.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Theodora didn’t know, did she? That you could talk -- or that you were Glinda’s spy. Kala doesn’t have to answer, because --

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Look-look -- here they are. And Oz turns and sees, in front of them: THE MIST MAIDENS -- beautiful, ghostly female apparitions they seem to be made of fog -- with flowing hair, flowing robes, flowing arms of white -- beckoning them forward...

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: They’1l guide us the rest of the way -- come-come.  46. Oz hesitates, then follows, the Maidens soon envelop them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fog is gone -- it’s a sunny day.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So he got away...

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: The Savage Generals have reported back. Evanora -- toying with the Diamond Dagger -- glances pointedly at Theodora.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: .-. heading South -- straight to Glinda, I suppose. (to the Generals) Leave us. The Generals troop out. The Sisters are alone.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: You see now I’m right -- either your Wizard and fair Glinda have been together from the start -- or they soon shall be. Which means, my pretty, that soon you must choose... between Glinda and me.

dialogues.speaker: THEODORA
dialogues.text: You're my Sister. How can you even think I’d choose Glinda over you?

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Because there’s still a part of you that still wants to be like Glinda: Beautiful... and beloved... rather than hated and feared, like me. (strokes Theodora’s hair) But that is not who you are, dear -- not who you are meant to be... I need you, Sister -- and halfway isn’t far enough. Join me... and together we'll defeat them -- join me, and together we shall rule for the next thousand years! (kisses Theodora’s cheek) And all it will cost you is your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Theodora’s look we bleed into a...  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word of Oz’s escape spreads throughout the land. We see VARIOUS CITIZENS in VARIOUS PLACES, talking on the sly.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS CITIZENS
dialogues.text: (like a song) Did you hear? The Wizard escaped -- he got away -- he walked through walls -- he disappeared -- he’s eight feet tall -- did you hear? EXT. OZ AND KALA —- ON THE ROAD SOUTH - MORNING Oz stops, hands on hips, peering off.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What’s that I’m looking at?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: That? That is Quadling Country, just on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: But on the other side of what? The reason he’s asking: Everything for the next half-mile so looks regular and normal, clear as a bell. Beyond that though, is what appears to be: A SHIMMERING WALL -- extending east to west as far as Oz see -- everything beyond it hazy as a mirage. Oz and Kala approach... Oz tentatively touches the Wall... can’t push through it -- it’s a force-field of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Glinda’s work as well, I take it. How do we get through?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: How do I know? I’m just a Monkey. You're a Wizard, you do something. Oz fumbles for a response -- and Kala laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Kala just kidding! And he smiles, raises up the Orb -- which suddenly LAUNCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: itself off his palm, shoots off into the Wall -- and when and Wall meet a sparkling PORTAL appears... Kala gestures Let’s go -- and the two pass through. The Wall closes beh them. And now they’re in:  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And 0z looks back at the Wall and marvels.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Y'know, back where I come from a man can get pretty fizzled on the same old usual. But around here, even the commonplace is really quite extraordinary, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Wizard, I leave you now. (off Oz’s surprise) I must speak to Glinda. You just take-take this road here -- bring you straight to Glinda’s Castle. You'll be alright. Just be careful when you cross the Ripple Land. And off he flies -- Oz shouting after him --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What’s the Ripple Land? Kala doesn’t answer, doesn’t even look back. Oz shrugs, starts walking. And soon he’s right smack in the middle o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is, as Baum describes it: ‘A succession of hills an valleys, all very steep and rocky, and they changed place constantly by rippling. While [0z] was climbing a hill it sank down under him and became a valley, and while he was descending into a valley it rose up and carried him to th top of a hill. This was very perplexing to the traveler.’ And so it is for Oz -- and at first he has a hell of a ti navigating his way across -- but eventually he makes it b to solid ground again -- and before long he finds himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he walks he notices his shoes are making a chinkin sound -- so he stops, raps that Gold Coin against the gro

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Sounds like... fine china.  49. He looks around, and sees: Everything around him seems to made of fine china -- the land, the trees, the farms, the horses and pigs and cows -- they’re all as smooth and shi as painted porcelain. Then he sees, near one of the barns A DAINTY CHINA GIRL -- teetering along the top of a fence dividing a Dainty China Chicken Coop from a Dainty China Sty. The Girl looks up -- Oz gives her a jaunty wave -- And, startled, the Girl loses her balance and tumbles int the pig sty just like Dorothy did in The Movie -- the Chi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pigs start squealing -- Oz comes running --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Sweet Jumpin’ Jiminy -- are you alright! -- then he sees: THE CHINA GIRL’S LEG HAS SNAPPED CLEAN O She sounds remarkably calm, albeit a bit perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: Could you help me up, please? He lifts her up out of the sty.

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: Now my leg? He reaches over the fence, hands her her leg.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Is there someone I should call? A doctor, or --?

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: No, my mother has some glue inside.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- I didn’t mean to startle you, I --

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: You're that Wizard they’ve been talking about, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: You don’t look much like a Wizard to me.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: What should a Wizard look like?  50.

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: Don’t know -- I’ve never seen one before. (beat) Thought you’d be bigger. She starts hobbling towards the house, using her detached as a cane, then looks back.

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: You will help us, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Um, sure I will. Sure. And you're sure you're alright?

dialogues.speaker: DAINTY CHINA GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm fine, thank you. She's gone -- and Oz remarks to himself --

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Fine, she says. Her leg snapped clean off her body but she’s fine. (then, to the China Pigs) Y'know, I’m about this close to losing my capacity for surprise? The China Pigs don’t care. Then one of the China Chickens plops out a DAINTY CHINA EGG. Oz reaches over the fence, picks it up, flicks it with a finger: Fine china.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Simply extraordinary. He sticks the China Egg in his pocket, walks on, while -- INT. THEODORA’S ROOM - EMERALD CITY - SAME Theodora winds the Music Box... starts DANCING to the music... eyes closed... alone... remembering... then she startles, seeing: Evanora’s come into the room.

dialogues.speaker: EVANORA
dialogues.text: Just thought you should know: Your Wizard is now in Quadling Country. (heads back out) Where, no doubt, he’ll soon be dancing with fair Glinda. She’s gone -- Theodora’s cheeks scald red.  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oz approaches a narrow mountain pass -- whistling to hims rolling that Gold Coin through his fingers -- then he hea

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop right there. Seeing: THE HAMMERHEADS -- three very short, squat, surly looking characters with flat-topped heads and no arms -- blocking the road in front of him. One snarls:

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Name’s Oz.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: Sure it is --

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: Listen, you, just ‘cause our heads are flat doesn’t mean they’re empty, so if you’ve got any brains in that noggin of yours you’1l turn right around and go back the way you came! No one comes through here without our say-so --

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: And to you we don’t say so, to you we say no --

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: So be gone and don’t delay!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: (sighs) Look, fellas, much as I’d like to be neighborly and obliging, I've come a long way and I really don’t have time for this.  52. And as he starts to push past them: Hammerhead #1’s head suddenly SHOOTS out from his body -- neck stretched like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack-in-the-Box -- and the flat part of his skull slams i Oz’'s gut -- knocks him flying into the air -- the Second Hammerhead deftly catches Oz on the flat of his head like soccer pro -- then he boings him into the air again -- Hammerhead #3’s turn next -- and the Hammerheads continue volleyball Oz back and forth like a human beanbag for a w -- and all Oz can do is oof and ouch until:

dialogues.speaker: KALA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You, boys, you stop it! KALA swoops in for a landing.

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: You cease these shenanigans! Glinda, she’s waiting for this man! The Hammerheads stop -- Oz hits the ground with a thud -- Hammerheads scowl, collectively --

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: What’s Glinda want with him?

dialogues.speaker: KALA
dialogues.text: Him, he is the Wizard! And the Hammerheads’ jaws drop.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: You're the Wizard? Why didn’t you say so? We’ve been waiting an awfully long time for you, y’know.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You have? Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: So you could get us our arms back.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: The Wicked Witch of the East, she took ‘em away -- and as long as she sits on the Emerald Throne we'll be like this --

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: Can’t even pick our noses. They all scowl again and nod. Oz says, falteringly --  53.

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: Okay, so... I'll speak to Glinda, see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMERHEAD
dialogues.text: We’re counting on you, Wizard!

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: You and everyone else, it seems. -- and he sounds burdened by that -- then, to Kala:

dialogues.speaker: OZ
dialogues.text: To Glinda’s, then. Off they go -- and soon, they come to it at last...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White, radiant, glorious -- seems to be made of living crystal. Oz is dazzled -- Kala leads him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the Gardens of Babylon -- but not a person to be see

dialogues.speaker: OZ
